Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT2480 - The Art Museum and Art Education","description":"

This course encompasses a consideration of core curatorial, interpretative and managerial roles within the sphere of the art museum, and how they have evolved over time. It adopts the perspective of the educator or member of the public who consumes art museum services. You are provided with mechanisms to unpack the often opaque subtexts of the art museum domain so that they can construct opportunities for access beyond the level of 'what you see is what you get'. You will be introduced to museum concepts in order to engender autonomous relationships with a range of art museums of interest to the professional educator and educated individual.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT2680 - Abstraction: from Kandinsky to Minimalism","description":"

Abstraction is one of the most important developments in twentieth-century art, this course traces the emergence of abstraction in Europe in the early part of the century (Kandinsky, Malevich, Mondrian) through to the deadpan literalism of American minimalism in the 1960s. Topics to be examined include: spiritual versus literal accounts of abstraction; various languages of abstraction (expressionism, constructivism, concretism); genres of abstract painting (the monochrome, the achrome); and historical movements centering on abstraction  (Kinetic Art, Abstract Expressionism, Unism, Spatilism, Brazilian Neo-Concretism, Colour field painting, Minimalism).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"025ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Tutorial Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will create and deliver tutorial presentations, and formulate 5 questions to generate discussion. Tutorial presentations will:

  • promote class discussion by highlighting issues raised by the reading. 
  • be well researched, research beyond the set reading is expected  
  • use images displayed in a powerpoint to illuminate aspects of the reading. Images should be as closely analysed as the reading itself.  
  • consider the approach of the reading, can you classify the approach eg is it art criticism or art history? Does it follow a particular method eg social history of art, feminist poststructuralist? What are the assumptions that underpin the reading eg does the reading assume the art being discussed is important, is it important aesthetically or socially, both, neither? Are there aspects of the reading that might be developed?
  • consider your topic in terms of its social and political implications today, and are there any representational/conceptual legacies of your topic in contemporary art? Are there new films/texts/exhibitions/documentaries that shed new light on the subject?

The lecturer will mark each assignment using the above criteria and provide written feedback with each student’s mark.

Students will produce a 2000 word research essay. 

Written feedback relating to assignment criteria will be provided by the lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"355ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3d5ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"795ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fd5ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"615ef83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Short Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Compare and contrast two forms of twentieth century abstraction with reference to three tutorial readings.

The reading summary should be 1-2 pages long (roughly 600 words) and written as a short essay.

The short essay should present:

  1. A clear and precise definition and interpretation of two forms of twentieth century abstraction.
  2. Use quotes where appropriate to support your interpretation. Make sure these are properly footnoted.
  3. Additional reading is not necessarily required; the aim is to read the tutorial readings closely, carefully and critically.

The lecturer will mark each assignment and provide written feedback with each student’s mark.

Asia-Pacific","description":"

The First Triennial of Asia-Pacific Art was held in Brisbane, Australia in 1993. From that period until the present these Asia-Pacific Triennials have become major events on the international art calendar as the event has grown from a relatively small one with a tight regional focus to one which includes China and India and covers half of the world's geography and more than half of the world's population. In this class the so-called 'rise of the APT' is examined from a number of perspectives: against the backdrop of the explosion of international art events known as Biennales of Art and against the question of the usefulness of the concept of an Asia-Pacific region, given changing economic and political conditions. Does this region have any uniformity or integration artistically, economically or politically? Whose art is included? What is excluded in events such as the APT? In sum the Asa-Pacific Treiennials are prisms with which to look at broader events in the region in the last twenty years. In this course we move from an in-depth examination of the history of the Asia-Pacific Triennials to an examination of other events and institutions such as the White Rabbit Gallery in Sydney and the 4A Gallery, as well as new state museums and cultural centres such as Tjibaou Cultural Centre in New Caledonia and Te Papa in New Zealand. This course is ideally designed to be studied after a student has taken SAHT3213, Museum Studies, in first semester.

From time to time, one-off opportunities arise for the College to offer special programs of study for credit. For example, supervised international experiences (such as study tours, exhibition participation or attendance, or special projects). This course is intended to facilitate the College in developing its educational program for undergraduate students by incorporating such opportunities into the academic program. Specific course outlines will be distributed detailing the academic content, objectives, assessment tasks and criteria, modes of teaching and learning, expectations and requirements of student participation. Please note that there may be costs involved (such as costs associated with travel, accommodation, meals and museum visits) in taking this course.

Thesis B","description":"

Thesis B follows on from Thesis A (SAHT 4211 normally completed in S1) and entails the completion of an Honours research thesis in art history/theory or visual culture of 15-18,000 words on an approved topic. At the conclusion of the course students will submit a research thesis to be assessed by both 2 examiners (1 internal and 1 external). Assigned supervisors guide students in their research and writing during the course of the semester through regular meetings and correspondence. Students also receive feedback and advice on their thesis research from the Course Convener via face-to-face meetings and email correspondence.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT6700","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT6700 - World Biennales: Field Trip","description":"

This course offers first-hand experience of biennales in various parts of the world. As part of this course, you will visit two to three biennale (or triennale) exhibitions over a two-week intensive. The exhibitions and their content will be examined from the point of view of various disciplines, such as curatorial, art history and theory. The course provides you with an understanding of contemporary, innovative approaches to art and exhibition-making. In addition to introductory seminars prior to departure as well as on-site discussions led by lecturers, you will hear from curatorial and/or education staff at the biennales, and, where possible, participating artists. Each course is unique, depending on which biennales are on in any given year. Generally, the course will cover European biennales one year (e.g. Venice, Istanbul, Lyon) and Asian biennales in the next year (e.g. Gwangju, Shanghai, Singapore, Sharjah). Note: You are responsible for your own travel arrangements and associated costs. An additional up-front fee is also required by the university to cover the cost of delivering a course overseas (specific details are confirmed each year).


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"49a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961945","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report: submitted after completion of the Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Journal/travel diary - Word length: 1500 (undergraduate); 2000 (postgraduate)

Content is not strictly prescribed but will be discussed on the field trip and can include images. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"01a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4da0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b4a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f0a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay: submitted prior to the Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Ten essay questions are set at the time of the course being advertised. This offers Students the maximum lead time to consider what most interests them about the biennales being visited. To an extent, it allows Students to individually customise their experience of the exhibitions. Questions cover a range of subjects around curatorial and theoretical issues. Undergraduates write 2,000 words; postgraduates write 3,000 words.
Essays are submitted for marking upon return. Written feedback from both lecturers is provided.

For this Assessment task, you will work with a partner to select, research and deliver to the class group a ten-minute presentation on a selected artwork. Your talk will critically engage with the work’s content, context and curatorial approach. You will be asked to work with a different partner on each occasion.

contentlets.description: This course offers first-hand experience of biennales in various parts of the world. As part of this course, you will visit two to three biennale (or triennale) exhibitions over a two-week intensive. The exhibitions and their content will be examined from the point of view of various disciplines, such as curatorial, art history and theory. The course provides you with an understanding of contemporary, innovative approaches to art and exhibition-making. In addition to introductory seminars prior to departure as well as on-site discussions led by lecturers, you will hear from curatorial and/or education staff at the biennales, and, where possible, participating artists. Each course is unique, depending on which biennales are on in any given year. Generally, the course will cover European biennales one year (e.g. Venice, Istanbul, Lyon) and Asian biennales in the next year (e.g. Gwangju, Shanghai, Singapore, Sharjah). Note: You are responsible for your own travel arrangements and associated costs. An additional up-front fee is also required by the university to cover the cost of delivering a course overseas (specific details are confirmed each year).
contentlets.title: World Biennales: Field Trip

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9110","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9110 - Australian Arts Ecology","description":"

Understanding the complex and dynamic Australian arts world is a key foundation for successful professional engagement in the cultural and creative field. This course maps the Australian arts world as an ecology and situates it within an Asia-Pacific and international arts context. It enables students to share and locate their cultural experience and knowledge within a critical overview of curatorial and cultural practice in Australia. 


The Australian arts ecology is composed of many interrelated and interacting layers of activity led by institutions, movements and individuals. This course will cover key areas including the history, development and role of arts collectives and artist-run institutions, commercial and public galleries, private and State foundations and collectors, and museums operating across a local, regional, national and international context.


The course explores particular historical and cultural interests, issues, events and perspectives that have shaped the Australian arts setting and are shaping contemporary discourse and directions. These include: indigenous culture, post-colonial settings, rural-urban realities, and the development of regional dialogue and hubs. The course addresses and critiques the increasing role of networks and networking in the cultural field, the conditions of globalisation, and concerns relating to sustainability and growth. 


The course works closely with Galleries UNSW and other industry partners, featuring three public guest lectures. This grounds the students in a sense that they are both discussing and constituting the Australian arts world, and aims to enhance networking skills and professional development.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2990f533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assignment is designed to evaluate your understanding of the core themes in the course and your ability to select key ideas, analyse them and shape an argument. Choose one essay title from the list posted in Week Two. You should review the relevant Lectures and weekly course materials to identify content, and pursue further independent research to support your essay. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9190f533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1590f533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assigment in designed to explore your ability to conduct in-depth research on a topic and situate this in the broader field of discussion in the course. For your case study, choose ONE organisation, event, or individual that you can argue has significantly shaped the Australian arts ecology at local, regional and/or national level. You may choose an example from the range discussed in the course to research further. A list of past student topics will also be posted in Week One. Two students may not choose the same topic. Your choice of case-study should reflect a key area of interest in the sector, or relate to work that you imagine doing in the sector in the future.

Use Media Collection on Moodle to create a case study that presents the historical and contemporary significance of your case study in 10-12 images, accompanied by texts. Maximum word limit for the whole case study: 1000 words. Your writing should include captions, basic information and description, analysis, supporting quotes where relevant, and be objective.

Understanding the complex and dynamic Australian arts world is a key foundation for successful professional engagement in the cultural and creative field. This course maps the Australian arts world as an ecology and situates it within an Asia-Pacific and international arts context. It enables students to share and locate their cultural experience and knowledge within a critical overview of curatorial and cultural practice in Australia. 

The Australian arts ecology is composed of many interrelated and interacting layers of activity led by institutions, movements and individuals. This course will cover key areas including the history, development and role of arts collectives and artist-run institutions, commercial and public galleries, private and State foundations and collectors, and museums operating across a local, regional, national and international context.

The course explores particular historical and cultural interests, issues, events and perspectives that have shaped the Australian arts setting and are shaping contemporary discourse and directions. These include: indigenous culture, post-colonial settings, rural-urban realities, and the development of regional dialogue and hubs. The course addresses and critiques the increasing role of networks and networking in the cultural field, the conditions of globalisation, and concerns relating to sustainability and growth. 

The course works closely with Galleries UNSW and other industry partners, featuring three public guest lectures. This grounds the students in a sense that they are both discussing and constituting the Australian arts world, and aims to enhance networking skills and professional development.

Critical writing is a key part of the contemporary art ecology and is changing rapidly alongside new digital technologies and networked practices. This course will introduce you to creative, critical, and professional art writing and publishing. You will engage with different modes of writing and publishing in relation to contemporary art and design. The role of writing and publishing in an increasingly interdisciplinary and digital context will be considered: this will include engagement with catalogue essays, curatorial statements, journal papers and online articles. The course focuses on the practice of writing (voice, register, style, structure and editing) and art and design communication strategies in the creative and cultural industries. You will engage with leading Australian arts publications to gain experience and knowledge in the field. You will also work individually and collaboratively to develop advanced critical reading, writing and editing skills.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5e903933db315c50eb6b147a3a96195c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Writing for publication","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will submit a 2500-word text written for a particular publication. A list of publications will be available on Moodle. With the lecturer's approval, a student may write for a publication of their choosing. Texts will be either: a long critical review of an exhibition/art work; findings from archival or primary research; a historical or theoretical essay; a critical study of arts policy or law. Students will research, draft and prepare their texts in accordance with the publication’s themes and styles and with consideration of the publication's readership. 

Texts must be referenced correctly. 

There will be an opportunity to workshop this assessment in class in the lead-up to submission. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d903933db315c50eb6b147a3a96193a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Response Diary","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Between Weeks 2–7, there are set themes and readings for class. Each week has multiple readings which will guide class discussion and activities.

For this assessment, students are asked to submit a 200-word response to ONE of the readings EACH week between Weeks 2–7 (excluding Week 6, which is a non-teaching week). Responses should be submitted to Moodle weekly, uploaded before the beginning of class. The assessment will be graded after submission in Week 7 of a final version of the five texts uploaded as a single PDF to Moodle. This means that entries can be edited before submission for grading; editing is strongly encouraged and can include reworking of the response in light of class discussion.  

The responses should NOT be review-style surveys but should be critical engagements with the text. This means doing some research to situate the text in its context, to consider its central argument/proposition, to analyse its style/structure/form/voice, and to reflect on its relation to key concepts and themes to do with contemporary art and culture. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f5903933db315c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis of a work","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will submit a 1000-word analysis of a current/recent artwork, event or performance. 

The analysis should consider the context of the work: the historical, social, cultural, and political meanings that contribute to the work and that affect any critical engagement. Students should also consider the relationship between the work and the analysis: is there a specific mode of analysis or form of response that makes more (or less) sense? How can the analysis reflect, in some way, the specificity of the work?

The analysis is not a standard review or description. It is a critical engagement with the work and can take the form of a response to, a critique of, or a departure from the work. The style and register of writing will be different depending on the form the analysis takes: what is important is to consider these differences carefully. Students will be assessed on their capacity to engage with the work and its context, to think critically and analytically, and to articulate coherently. Students must properly cite all references to research materials and must take care to proofread and edit their work before submission. 

There will opportunities to discuss Assessment 1 in Weeks 2, 3, and 4.

contentlets.keywords: art history,art writing,publishing,critical writing,online publishing,art criticism,creative communication
contentlets.description: Critical writing is a key part of the contemporary art ecology and is changing rapidly alongside new digital technologies and networked practices. This course will introduce you to creative, critical, and professional art writing and publishing. You will engage with different modes of writing and publishing in relation to contemporary art and design. The role of writing and publishing in an increasingly interdisciplinary and digital context will be considered: this will include engagement with catalogue essays, curatorial statements, journal papers and online articles. The course focuses on the practice of writing (voice, register, style, structure and editing) and art and design communication strategies in the creative and cultural industries. You will engage with leading Australian arts publications to gain experience and knowledge in the field. You will also work individually and collaboratively to develop advanced critical reading, writing and editing skills.
contentlets.title: Art Writing and Publishing

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9113","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9113 - Cultural Heritage, Ethics & the Law","description":"

Accountability and responsibility are two of the key issues at the heart of every cultural transaction and exchange. Therefore a strong professional understanding of ethics and the law are essential for graduates aspiring to curatorial roles and cultural leadership.


This course is designed to examine the ethical and legal implications of interactions between artists, curators, exhibiting spaces and the public. It will enable the development of a broad critical perspective on the cultural, legal, political and moral contexts of mainstream and alternate cultural spaces. Issues discussed include theft and illegal export of cultural heritage items, curatorial conflicts, contracts, copyright, moral rights, art in public spaces, and censorship.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cf903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Analysis Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

PART A – REACTION PIECE (10%)

Each student selects one topic (different from the topic of their Tutorial Presentation) and writes a 250-word Reaction Piece of the allocated reading. The purpose of the Reaction Piece is to show that you have thought carefully and analytically about the case addressed by the reading, and to help spark discussion and thought among your peers online and in class. Your Reaction Piece needs to be written clearly and logically and move beyond summarising the contents of the reading. It might contain a combination of the following: 

* Critically assess the relative merits of the author's argument and provide reasons for your perspective (What's compelling, what's not and why?) 

* Connect the content of the reading to content discussed in class when this topic was covered, or to current issues and events within the artworld.

The Reaction Piece is due at the end of week 3.

 

PART B - CRITICAL RESPONSES (20%)

Due: from the Wednesday following in-class coverage of the topic. 

Assessment length: 200 words x by at least 4 Critical Responses (at least 800 words). 

Assessment Summary: To support your peers in generating in-class discussion each week all students are required at least 4 times during the semester to respond critically and analytically to a PART A REACTION PIECE. After carefully reading the relevant course reading, you might add a comment that endorses or disagrees with opinions advanced. You might consider framing your argument based on new material, other available peer opinions, an alternate context, or your own experience. 

Please remember: always be respectful and professional. The purpose of CRITICAL RESPONSES is to demonstrate that you have thought carefully and critically about one or more readings, to communicate your ideas clearly and logically and to facilitate further class discussion. * Please post your CRITICAL RESPONSES to the discussion thread for the topic set up on Moodle. 1. Go to the Moodle site for SAHT9113 via MyUNSW Click on ‘Discussion Forum’ then select the relevant weekly topic. Read your peers’ REACTION PIECE then add your CRITICAL RESPONSE

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f2903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66903933db315c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial presentation (small group) and short paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

During the term, students will be required, in groups of two or three (we will decide that in the first class), to make a presentation on one of the themes indicated in the class outline. You and your partners are required to present a case study on the topic you have been assigned (based on your preferences). Please read the guide below for the assignment.

In presenting the case, you will need to discuss the relevant legal and ethical principles and how these apply in the particular case, analyse underlying assumptions and tensions, and suggest alternative or additional approaches that may have been available.

Presenting the Case: On the day your topic is discussed in class, you and your partner(s) will make a 15-20 minute presentation (with 20 minutes the absolute upper limit). Each member of the group will to both contribute to any PowerPoint for the class and participate in the presentation. The aim of the presentation is to provide any necessary context to the case (for example, historical, theoretical, doctrinal) and then walk the class through a close reading of it, connecting it to the larger themes and tensions of the topic.

Paper relating to the case: On the day you present, you will need to provide the lecturer with a paper on the topic allocated to you. Paper should be between 1 to 2 pages of double spaced type (max 600 words), with font no smaller than 9 point and should prepared by you individually (that is, not to be a joint effort with other members of your group).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66903933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The research essay is designed to allow students to demonstrate their ability to formulate their own reasoned opinions about core problems addressed in the course. Assessment will be based on the quality and originality of your analysis of the topic you have chosen, as well as the demonstrated knowledge of the relevant legal principles applicable: see the marking rubric below for further information. To do well in the essay, you must demonstrate core disciplinary knowledge, the capacity to think and present written arguments clearly and to engage in a critical analysis of the relevant legal and ethical issues.

Essays must be submitted by 6 p.m. on Tuesday week 9, both via Turnitin and in hardcopy to the lecturer.

Save for exceptional circumstances, no extensions will be granted. Any request for an extension must be submitted to the lecturer in advance of the due date and supporting documentation of incapacity or misadventure provided through a request for

Special Consideration via myUNSW. Work submitted late without an extension will be penalized at a rate of 10% per day up to a maximum of 100%.

Topic: A variety of topics will be made available for you to choose from in Week 2, but you are encouraged to select your own topic, provided you first discuss that topic with the lecturer.

Word length: Your essay should be between 1,500 and 2,000 words. It must explore a legal or ethical principle in the museum or curatorial professions in depth, with reference to real-life examples, and relevant legal rules, cases and principles.

This course examines the theoretical and practical aspects of exhibition management. It develops a knowledge of curatorial procedures with particular reference to the initiation, presentation, interpretation and planning of art works in exhibition settings. Specific attention is paid to the administrative skills necessary to mount exhibitions, the production of visual and written documentation and the methods of critical engagement with images and objects. Visits to exhibitions as well as participation in the planning and implementation of an exhibition form an essential part of this subject. Students undertaking this course must first complete at least three of the following core courses: SAHT9111, SAHT9112, SAHT9113 and SAHT9126.

contentlets.description: This course examines the theoretical and practical aspects of exhibition management. It develops a knowledge of curatorial procedures with particular reference to the initiation, presentation, interpretation and planning of art works in exhibition settings. Specific attention is paid to the administrative skills necessary to mount exhibitions, the production of visual and written documentation and the methods of critical engagement with images and objects. Visits to exhibitions as well as participation in the planning and implementation of an exhibition form an essential part of this subject. Students undertaking this course must first complete at least three of the following core courses: SAHT9111, SAHT9112, SAHT9113 and SAHT9126.
contentlets.title: Exhibition Management and Curatorial Studies

Students undertake a project-based industry placement internship consisting of a minimum of 240 hours. This may involve more than one host institution. Internships enable students to gain practical, supervised experience of gallery management, curatorial practice, public programs, art writing and other work areas related to the course. The internship is ungraded but successful completion requires the submission of reports both by the host institution and the student. Students are also required to participate in an on-line discussion during their internship and their final report is posted on the WebCt site. Internships have been hosted locally, interstate and overseas by many arts organisations including: the National Gallery of Australia, Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York), The Getty (Los Angeles), The Guggenheim (New York and Venice), Art Institute of Chicago, Museum of Modern Art, Chicago, Art Gallery of New South Wales, regional and commercial galleries in New South Wales, Sotheby's Australia Pty Ltd, Australian Centre for Photography, State Library of New South Wales, Visual Arts/Craft Board of the Australia Council, Powerhouse Museum, and the Ministry for the Arts, New South Wales. Students undertaking this course must first complete at least three of the following core courses: SAHT9111, SAHT9112, SAHT9113 and SAHT9126. They should also have completed at least three core options as outlined in the program structure.

The Research Paper course provides students in the final term of the Master of Curating and Cultural Leadership (MCCL) with the opportunity to produce an analytical, critical and reflective scholarly research paper on an approved topic of their choice. The topics you choose to investigate are expected to relate to the disciplinary area of curatorial practice and cultural leadership. This course utilises both self and peer review with the aim of developing your skills for providing well-considered constructive criticism. It aims to extend your ability to work collaboratively in groups while reflecting on your future profession as curators and cultural leaders. To enrol, you must be in the last term of your degree, and have a minimum Weighted Average Mark (WAM) of 70.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ac4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Topic, Scope And Case Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The first assessment is comprised of two parts

Part 1

The first part requires you to undertake the following tasks.  These tasks are:

  1. Choose a topic, make sure it is guided by a series of key concepts and that it has a clear scope. Identify the topic in 2-5
  1. Develop an annotated bibliography on your topic: it will be comprised of 5 scholarly references (books, book chapters, journal articles) that are central to your You will write 250 word summariesof each reference. Follow guidelines here on how to develop an annotated bibliography: https://student.unsw.edu.au/annotated-bibliography
  1. Choose yourcase studies (eg on curatorial projects/curatorial or exhibition theory and histories; cultural leadership). Include 2-5 examples that you think are relevant to your research paper, topic and question/s. In 150 words concisely introduce the case studies and note why you think they are relevant to your Be sure to include image captions, formatted correctly underneath each image.
  1. Develop a research question: What is that you think you are asking or wanting to research in your paper? What question/s might navigate your research paper? Come up with 1 research question or 2 interconnected research
  1. Develop a thesis statement. Based on your chosen case studies AND yourannotated bibliography, develop a thesis statement (1-2 sentences). In class, we will cover how to develop a thesis preceding the submission date for this assessment. However, a good guidefor how to develop a thesis is here: https://writingcenter.fas.harvard.edu/pages/developing-thesis

When submitting your assessment be sure to structure it using the headings below:

  1. Topic
  1. Annotated bibliography
  1. Case studies (eg artworks/exhibitions/curatorial projects).
  1. Research question
  1. Thesis

Part 2

In class, you will be required to present (in 8 mins) on  the below:

  1. Topic (including the title of your research paper, and how/why you selected this topic)
  1. Research question
  1. Proposed thesis
  1. The discourse your project, and research question/s, emerges out of (this will be based on your annotated bibliography).
  1. 1-3 selected, and relevant case studies (that help you answer your research question).
  1. Questions you have on challenges/problems you are facing related to developing your research paper/topic

You can consult this guide while developing your assessment, and research paper overall: https://writing.wisc.edu/Handbook/PlanResearchPaper.html

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"284fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"644fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"184fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research ProposalResearch Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The second assessment is in two parts:

Part 1

Students will prepare a research proposal to develop their research paper.

The Research Proposal includes the following components (use bolded subheadings as listed below in your submission):

  1. Abstract (250 words max) - write it last but place at the top of your Use this guide: https://writingcenter.unc.edu/tips-and-tools/abstracts/
  2. Background/Introduction- introduce us to your topic:why are you investigating this research topic? What do you find interesting about it? What might your reading of the topic contribute to existing knowledge or discourse? Include your research question and thesis in this section (integrated into the introduction'snarrative).
  3. Literature review - offer an assessment of the field which pertains to your topic (this will be based on your annotated bibliography from assessment1). Usethis

guide: https://libguides.library.cqu.edu.au/litreview  or this

guide: https://www.rlf.org.uk/resources/what-is-a-literature-review/

  1. MethodsandCaseStudies-whatareyourmethods/approaches?Whattheoreticalframeworkswill you use? Which case studies will you focus on? Make surethat these are strongly aligned withyour research question and help advance your In this section, outline why you are making the choices you are making regarding your  methods/approach/case studies.
  2. Timeline - What will you need to do by when to complete your research paper? Develop a clear timeline to
  3. Significance of Research - Why does yourresearch matter? Think in terms of the field/discipline (so be specific) but also think about how/if it might matter regarding bigger questions, outside the field/discipline.
  4. References - List of 10 references that are central to the research topic. Choose one citation style (Oxford, Chicago, or MLA, for example, and stick with it): Use guides here: Chicago:http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org; Oxford: http://guides.library.uwa.edu.au/c.php?g=325241&p=2177430;MLA:http://guides.lib.monash.edu/citing-referencing/mla

Part 2

In class, you will present for 8 mins on the following aspects of your research proposal:

  1. Background/Introduction (to topic, with research question and thesis)
  2. An overview of the field/key discourses related to your topic - (based on the Literature Review)
  3. Methods and Case Studies
  4. Significance of Research

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"284fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"644fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"504fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students write a Research Paper (long essay) of 5000 words (not including citations or bibliography). Include an abstract with your research paper. The topics students choose to investigate are expected to relate to the disciplinary area of curating and/or cultural leadership.

The research paper is an extended essay, similar to a scholarly journal article; it is not a dissertation comprising multiple chapters (which would be closer to a book). The structure of the research paper will be discussed in class in more detail.

The topics you choose to investigate are expected to relate to the disciplinary area of curatorial practice and cultural leadership. This course utilises both self and peer review with the aim of developing your skills for providing well-considered constructive criticism. It aims to extend your ability to work collaboratively in groups while reflecting on your future profession as curators and cultural leaders. To enrol, you must be in the last term of your degree, and have a minimum Weighted Average Mark (WAM) of 70.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9117","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9117 - Contemporary Curating: Theories and Practices","description":"

Contemporary curating is a dynamic profession that responds to and initiates cultural change. It is a practice that is continually being re-examined and reinvented. At the same time it has a long and rich history that intersects with the histories of art production, material culture, aesthetic experience, collection, display and the institutions of museums and galleries. 


This course investigates contemporary curatorial practices and the theories that inform them. It examines current debates in light of the historical evolution of the profession, including issues such as globalization, technological change, shifting notions of the public, spatial politics, new theories of objecthood, reconsiderations of art institutions, alternative views of time and history and interdisciplinary collaborations. 


The course pays special attention to experimental and innovative forms of curating and the particular kinds of new knowledge produced through curatorial practice. Through a close examination of the work of a diverse range of curators it builds an understanding of the individuality of curatorial practice as well as the shared languages, concerns and skills that define the field. 


The course is delivered in collaboration with Galleries UNSW and other industry partners to offer guest lectures and seminars by outstanding Australian and international curators.

The course pays special attention to experimental and innovative forms of curating and the particular kinds of new knowledge produced through curatorial practice. The Capstone Project is undertaken in the last study period prior to graduation and gives MCCL students the opportunity to integrate their previous studies, consolidate their skills, address authentic problems and develop a strong identity as a professional in the cultural industries.
Students can undertake the capstone either through an industry internship or through a self-directed cultural project. There may also be the opportunity to take part in facilitated group cultural projects through the Sydney Culture Network alliance of arts and cultural organisations.


The internship option involves a project-based industry placement with a minimum of 150 hours. Internships enable students to gain practical, supervised experience in an organisational context. Internships should be organised before the commencement of term.
The independent project option requires students to develop, execute and evaluate a cultural project such as exhibition, exhibition proposal or exhibition grant application, screenings, discussions, performances, festivals, websites and site-specific events. Individual or team projects are developed in consultation with the lecturer. Students are individually supervised and submit reports on the progress and completion of the project.


For both options students are supported through online forums, and professional and peer support workshops.
Successful completion of the course requires the submission of an initial, ongoing and final reports. SAHT9118 is ungraded.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5dfcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961978","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The essay should analyse the Project undertaken against the original Project proposal and implementation plan, as outlined in Assessment Tasks #1 and #2.

As a guide, topics for inclusion might include: Expectations; Negotiations with stakeholders; Planning the project; Aspects that went according to plan; Aspects that did not go according to plan; Reflection on experience; Future plans.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"59fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"95fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ddfcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class presentation and project research summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

5-minute class presentation + 1,000-word paper. You should detail your project research including affinity with interests and long term career strategy, theoretical background and concept development. The class presentation should be a pecha kucha style presentation: 5 minutes with a maximum of 20 slides. The subsequent paper should take on board feedback received in class and need not include images.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1dfcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Note: After consultation with the Course Convener, if necessary students can start the Capstone Project before Tem starts and finish after Term ends.

SAHT9118 Capstone Project is designed to give students real-world experience in a particular area of professional practice. This could be a commercial gallery, museum, public gallery, artist-run initiative or arts funding body in Australia or internationally. The report is submitted during the first few weeks of the Project and can take the form of a chart or dot points totaling no more than 1,000 words. It should include: Background to the Project and institution (if applicable); key performance targets over the duration; methodology for delivery of the project, and; anticipated outcomes.

contentlets.description:
The Capstone Project is undertaken in the last study period prior to graduation and gives MCCL students the opportunity to integrate their previous studies, consolidate their skills, address authentic problems and develop a strong identity as a professional in the cultural industries.
Students can undertake the capstone either through an industry internship or through a self-directed cultural project. There may also be the opportunity to take part in facilitated group cultural projects through the Sydney Culture Network alliance of arts and cultural organisations.

The internship option involves a project-based industry placement with a minimum of 150 hours. Internships enable students to gain practical, supervised experience in an organisational context. Internships should be organised before the commencement of term.
The independent project option requires students to develop, execute and evaluate a cultural project such as exhibition, exhibition proposal or exhibition grant application, screenings, discussions, performances, festivals, websites and site-specific events. Individual or team projects are developed in consultation with the lecturer. Students are individually supervised and submit reports on the progress and completion of the project.

For both options students are supported through online forums, and professional and peer support workshops.
Successful completion of the course requires the submission of an initial, ongoing and final reports. SAHT9118 is ungraded.
contentlets.title: Capstone Project

This course considers two areas of design development. These are the theoretical and practical aspects of exhibition design and display techniques and the specific design demands of a gallery space. The ways in which the objectives of an exhibition may be identified are discussed, and all aspects related to project initiation and completion examined. These include planning and design management, budget formulation and controls, production and installation management, spatial requirements and evaluation, light and lighting.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9122","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9122 - Audience Engagement","description":"

Many cultural institutions today consider audiences to be at the centre of their operations. This new focus on audiences, has also seen education as core business of cultural institutions. Such shifts in thinking are evidenced in a variety of ways including for example, the increasing importance of 'pedagogy' within curatorial practice.


New ways of conceptualising and understanding the public are being developed to better accommodate the varied needs of those who visit museums and galleries. At the same time, professionals within public programs departments are developing a wide range of programs and events that promise to engage, educate and entertain visitors at almost every stage of their life.


To gain a competitive edge arts professionals are also striving to attract and maintain the interests of their virtual visitors through social and locative media and new digital platforms. The rapid rise of affordable internet access enables many people to engage interactively with the museum professionals who make key decisions about what is presented and why.


This course is designed to assist future professionals to understand current models of interpretation and to use this knowledge to create new ways of enhancing visitors' engagement with art. The content covered includes a critical analysis of key historic and contemporary interpretive strategies as well as associated learning theories that underpin these strategies.


Using real world examples, the connection between audience engagement and the evolving practices of exhibition-making, installation and display will be highlighted.


This course equips you to make context-based assessments about the professional requirements of audience engagement, and helps you understand how to design and implement appropriate projects and programs while achieving key organisational goals.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bbf3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961978","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Engagement and Exchange","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

To encourage online and in-class discussion, students are required to write and post three short critical responses to a required course reading (Topics assigned in W1) and three comments responding to other students posts.

After carefully reading the selected course reading, post a 200 word response (3 x 200 words) for each reading that uses the author's argument as a point of departure.

Rather than summarising each author's findings, you might consider:

·       relating points made to your own experience.

·       raising questions or comments from online & in-class discussion.

·       relating points made by the author to current issues within the sphere of art museums and audience engagement.

Students are also required to comment on at least three other student’s posts. When commenting consider:

·       How can you build upon or extend the ideas that others have offered?

·       Are there ideas you have encountered in other readings or exhibitions that you can use to illustrate interesting links or resonances?

·       If you want to offer a counter point or challenge someone elses ideas then be sure to think about the way you word it. We want to encourage exchange not discourage or shut anyone down.

These posts and exchanges can be made anytime between weeks 2 – 8 but you must make your first post by week 3 so that informal feedback via email can be given. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3bf3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2bf3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Programming for Different Audiences","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this task, students are required to research the public program OR education program in relation to the curatorial premise of 2 exhibitions of contemporary art in 2 different art contexts that you have recently seen in a Sydney gallery, contemporary art space or art museum.

Example:

1)    Exhibition/public program at MCA

2)    Exhibition/education program at AGNSW

Choose examples of art initiatives that target a specific  audience (i.e. children and families, teens, people from culturally or linguistically diverse backgrounds).

The task is to write a 2000 word essay that critically analyses one example of a specific public program OR education initiative from each context/institution. Essays should address the objectives of the public program OR education program, the relationship of the public program or education strategies to the exhibition's curatorial premise (main idea); What was done, why was it done, and for whom? What could be done differently?

Students will share their findings with peers in a Roundtable Discussion in class time Week 7. The roundtable accounts for 5% of the assessment’s 30% weight.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"77f3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63f3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Developing Interpretive Strategies","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students select one of the examples discussed in Assessment 2 to develop questioning strategies for communicating/animating content about one artist/artwork/exhibition.

This assessment is to include:

1.     A research paper (1300 words) that discusses a) the content, form and significance of the selected artwork in relation to the artist's practice and to the exhibition concept b) the rationale for the type of questions used in the floortalk.

2.     Using 3 slides only, develop a short ‘floortalk’ that incorporates appropriate questioning strategies to convey/animate content about the artist/artwork/exhibition concept to the audience.

3.     Student Presentations: Each student provides a short in-class presentation that highlights the key points of the floortalk and which briefly explains the rationale for the approach to animating the content of the selected art work.  

4.     On the day of the Student Presentations, students submit tour notes + powerpoint presentation (NB both are separate to the 1300 word research paper allocated for this assessment).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bff3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63f3bc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SAHT9122.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9124","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9124 - Cultural Management and Policy","description":"

This course introduces students to some of the key skills and knowledge required to work in the cultural sector, including: establishing organisations, organisational governance and business planning, as well as policy and funding frameworks. It reviews the development of cultural policy and implementation in Australia, as a key context for cultural sector organisations.  


This course will consider the development of national and regional cultural infrastructure and the factors determining the allocation of public funding. A variety of organisational forms will be considered and comparisons with international models considered.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0efcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619db","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Business Plan or Grant Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will either select to prepare a Business Plan or a Grant Application to complete this assessment. 

Both of these options will assist you in developing important planning and development skills invaluable to cultural projects, including professional communication skills. While both documents serve different purposes – the skills required are similar, and include:

·       clearly and simply explaining the idea and its purpose

·       writing to generate interest, with the overall goal of persuading readers (I.e. both internal (Dept Heads / Boards) and external (funding bodies)) of the value of the endeavor. 

For both options, while the idea is important, the process of developing it is the focus of this task. Especially if you are new to this field, you are encouraged to start small and choose something that might be feasible for you to deliver given your skills and experience. A very simple idea can be developed into an innovative and creative offering through planning and development and careful analysis and reflection on the project and its contexts. It is also important to consider how you can communicate your ideas beyond the text, by incorporating select images and considering layout options. 

In terms of the Business Plan option, you should follow the structure available in terms of the Strategic Plan in Colbert (1998) including: the vision and/or the mission; analysis of the environment; analysis of the organisation; strategic goals; action plan; and review mechanisms.

If you choose to complete a Grant Application, you should find a grant that would be applicable to your project idea. For example, if you are working locally, you may consider applying to a local council, or, if it is for a student project, you might consider the Kudos Grant rounds. Part of the task, for this option, is to identify a relevant funding body for the project and use their application format. Common elements can include: applicant details; project title & summary; project outline; expected outcomes; deliverables; support materials and attachments. 

Please note: Grant Applications can vary in the elements required.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0efcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4afcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"39fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflections on Readings","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The ability to communicate your ideas in a public setting is crucial to success. Consequently, each student is expected to contribute to the discussion both in class and on Moodle. You are required to make posts in Moodle which demonstrate your understanding of the weekly readings, provide a reflection on the related themes and arguments and adds to the class discussion by sharing related links to relevant external websites as well. A prompt will be provided for each topic which may include a guiding question to focus your response.

Each week before class (minimum 7 entries out of the 9 teaching weeks) you will be required to post a response (up to 400 words) which includes:

• a summary of the Readings (main lines of argument)

• commentary on the readings (your analysis of the arguments, how they relate to you, your practice, your community, etc., further context on the author or topic and/or any further supporting or contrary views or opinions)

• at least one link to a relevant website, e.g. current events, articles or debates (this may include video or text-based sources e.g. news articles, example professional projects, as well as academic sources such as journal papers) and comment why you have chosen to share the link(s).

You will be required to post at least 24 hours before each class. This will allow time for the interesting links to current events / articles to be reviewed by your tutor and classmates and then discussed in class. General rules about maintaining positive online discussions need to be maintained.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0efcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cefcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"71fcf07bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Investigating Cultural Policies","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

You will investigate an arts/cultural policy from a state or local government in Australia or overseas. You will present your findings in a 5-minute presentation, pecha kucha style (maximum 5 slides). Your chosen policy will be decided by Week 2 (in Moodle).

A maximum of two people can speak on the same location. If you wish to do the same location as another class member you have the option to undertake one 10-minute presentation. Once the location has been chosen twice it cannot be undertaken by any other student. Students will be assessed individually.

You will also be required to submit a summary of your presentation in Moodle on the day of the assessment.

Key questions to consider in the presentation and write-up:

•Key point/s of the policy, outcomes, goals, aims.

•How was it developed/created?

•What does it aim to achieve?

•How is success measured?

•What areas does it cover?

•What are its strengths and weaknesses? How could it be improved?

•What sort of responses would it promote from the artistic / creative communities?

Presentations will need to comply with the 5- minute allocation so other students will have sufficient time to present.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9125 - The Australian Art Market","description":"

This course investigates the art market as a process of bringing art works to sale. It offers an historical overview from the Renaissance artists workshops and guilds and a detailed study of contemporary Australian art. The subject explores the development of patronage, taste and collecting, and the impact of these phenomena on the subsequent rise of the international art market. Key elements in the Australian art market under investigation in this course include the fragmentation of the art market, Australian Movable Cultural Heritage, and artistic reputation. The subject assists students to understand commodification in the art world and the processes by which artworks are brought to sale.

contentlets.description: This course investigates the art market as a process of bringing art works to sale. It offers an historical overview from the Renaissance artists workshops and guilds and a detailed study of contemporary Australian art. The subject explores the development of patronage, taste and collecting, and the impact of these phenomena on the subsequent rise of the international art market. Key elements in the Australian art market under investigation in this course include the fragmentation of the art market, Australian Movable Cultural Heritage, and artistic reputation. The subject assists students to understand commodification in the art world and the processes by which artworks are brought to sale.
contentlets.title: The Australian Art Market

This course provides individuals working in an arts based organisation with competencies relevant to the inter-personal and inter-group skills demanded in the efficient and effective management of organisations. It aims to fulfil the needs of individuals interested in the principles of planning, organisation, communication and evaluation of personnel within an organisation and, as well, the needs of directors and supervisors who wish to develop expertise in essential personnel management aspects of their job within an appropriate theoretical framework.

This course introduces a comparative study of contemporary visual art and museum cultures in the Asia Pacific. As arts professionals - curators, administrators, writers, etc - develop relationships with colleagues through the region, an understanding, not only of the visual arts but also of the museum sector, is becoming essential. Case studies of international exhibitions, and related arts programs, will be examined.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5561e53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Research and write an account of an institution, a project or an initiative in the region. Length excludes footnotes and references.  

After receiving confirmation of your topic you are required to submit a 500 word (maximum) plan for your essay by week six.  This task is compulsory but not assessable. You will receive feedback on your plan. 

Your essay should address the institution, project or initiative in terms of: 

Its geographical and cultural situation; 

Its formation and history;

Its activities in terms of their relationship to practitioners, audiences/stakeholders, colleagues/competitors and capacity building;

Its relationship to art histories, exhibition histories and curatorial histories in the region and beyond;

Its relationship to at least three pertinent topics discussed during the course eg rise of art fairs, repatriation, climate change, feminism, the training/formative professional experiences of personnel, cultural diplomacy; and

Its futures (plural).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5161e53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5961e53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9d61e53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0d61e53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Present a project proposal as an illustrated 5 - 10 minute presentation (with 5 additional minutes for questions). Provide a one-page (only) hand out for the class. The hand out will be viewed in relation to its communication objectives (eg providing basic proposal information, listing key dates and locations, providing pronunciation and naming customs, including a map or a chart). 

In your presentation and paper you need to identify: 

- - The form of your project – an exhibition (eg solo commission; group show), performance, an online publishing project, a series of panel discussions etc;

- - The institution, situation or context that your proposal addresses;

--  Why you chose the context and the project form;

-   An analysis of a practice that has inspired your proposal (e.g. images of an artist's work)
