","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9138","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9138 - Global Contemporary Art","description":"

This course introduces you to global contemporary art; art that critically reflects, responds to and intervenes in the key forces shaping the present condition. Globalisation, border politics and decolonisation are the key socio-historical contexts for this course, as you examine art’s relationship with, and response to, economic, historical, ecological, and political contexts. To navigate the breadth and complexity of global contemporary art, you will engage with a series of key concepts such as ‘contemporaneity’ and ‘global art’, drawing from a range of contemporary writers and artists. By doing so, you will develop a vocabulary and tool kit, grounded in theory and practice, through which to critically engage with the intersections of art, culture, and the processes and politics of making and re-making worlds today. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"18a07933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation on Key Concept","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The aim of this assessment is for you and other students to gain a strong sense of key concepts/vocabularies used in this course through both independent work and collaborative dialogue in tutorials that ensue from the class presentations. 

There will be further readings for this task (i.e. not the mandatory weekly class readings). The list of assessment readings will be available in Moodle and the presentation slots will be allocated in tutorials on Week 1.

You will deliver a presentation of 7 minutes duration in a week that you will nominate during tutorials in Week 1. Presentations will commence week 2.

You are to introduce the class to the key concept for the relevant week. You are to develop an understanding of this concept based on the allocated reading. You are then expected to succinctly communicate yourinterpretation of the key concept to the class. Stick to what matters – the task here is not to give us a run-down or summary of the article, as much as how youinterpret the set reading and key concept:

  • How is the key concept defined in the set reading, and why? 
  • What is the most compelling or problematic interpretation of the key concept in the allocated reading?
  • Why might such a concept be central to art in the 21stcentury? 

These are some examples of questions you can ask yourself while you read the set essay and prepare for the presentation. You can show us some images or artworks to help us get a sense of the particular interpretation of the key concept you are trying to communicate to us, but this is not compulsory.  Use text and images in PowerPoint/Keynote wisely. 

Towards the end of your presentation, offer some provocations and/or questions. The idea here is for your provocations/questions to lead into a class discussion on the key concept, andhow it might help us better understand art in the 21stcentury. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04a07933db315c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

IMPORTANT NOTE: while you may reference works made in the pre-2000 period as background, all your key case studies must be artworks produced after 2000. This is a course on art in the 21stcentury after all!

This assessment requires you to write a 2200-word essay in response to your research question/s (developed in Assessment 2). This assessment is designed to strengthen your writing and research skills, and your understanding of key concepts and themes in the course. The open nature of the brief also offers you an opportunity to develop your distinct research interests relevant to art in the 21stcentury. 

You will develop your essay over the semester and will receive feedback at key intervals from your tutor and peers. You can use text that you developed for your annotated bibliography in Assessment 2; however, you are expected to edit and refine your writing based on feedback. Your final essay should reference at least 7 scholarly resources.

You should pay close attention to scholarly presentation, including clear expression, legibility, essay structure, correct formatting of references and bibliography. 

This course follows the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system. Guidelines on how to reference according to this system can be found at: 

  • https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnote-bibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system   https://student.unsw.edu.au/citing-different-sources-0  
  • https://student.unsw.edu.au/bibliography-or-list-references
","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04a07933db315c50eb6b147a3a96199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

In this assessment, you will develop your research topic and essay question that you will then investigate for your final assessment (Assessment 3). This assessment is designed to develop your research skills relevant to the analysis of contemporary art – including your own practice. While not essential, even if you are an artist, you are more than welcome to attempt to theorise/write about your own practice using the key concepts and themes covered in this course. 

You are required to undertake the following tasks for this Assessment:

  1. Choose a topic, make sure it focuses on one of the key concepts/weekly themes from the course. Identify the topic you will investigate in 2-5 sentences.

(150 words max)

  1. Choose your case studies (eg artworks, curatorial projects, exhibitions). Make sure they are all from the 21stcentury (from 2000 onwards). Include 2-3 examples that you think are relevant to your research topic. Concisely introduce each of your case studies (150 words per case study), explaining why you think each is relevant to your topic. Be sure to include correctly formatted image captions underneath each image. Correct formatting for image captions is as follows: author, artwork title (italicised), year and medium, e.g. Tania Bruguera, Immigrant Movement International, 2012. Mixed media 

(500 words max)

  1. Develop a research question: What is that you think you are asking or wanting to research in your essay? What question/s might navigate your research? Come up with 1 research question or 2 interconnected research questions 

(150 words max)

  1. Develop an annotated bibliography on your topic: it will be comprised of 4 scholarly references (books, book chapters, journal articles) that are central to your topic. You will write a 250-word summary of each reference. Follow guidelines on how to develop an annotated bibliography here:

 https://student.unsw.edu.au/annotated-bibliography

(1000 words max)

  1. Develop a thesis statement. Based on your chosen case studies AND your annotated bibliography, develop a thesis statement (1-2 sentences). In class, we will cover how to develop a thesis preceding the submission date for this assessment. However, a good guide for how to develop a thesis is here: https://writingcenter.fas.harvard.edu/pages/developing-thesis 

(150 words max)

When submitting your assessment be sure to structure it using the headings below:

  1. Topic
  2. Case studies (eg artworks/exhibitions/curatorial projects)
  3. Research question
  4. Annotated bibliography
  5. Thesis statement

This course introduces a number of theoretical lenses for understanding contemporary design practice. The course takes you through key aspects of the current profession and discipline of design, explaining their histories. The course will focus on the principles and techniques of experts designing around the world. The course involves a series of researched case studies, giving you experiences of historically and culturally distinct ways of conducting design. Themes include: Craft and Design, Design Management, Consumerism, Design Education Institutions, Social Design, Design Futures, Design Methods, Post-Industrial Design. By the end of the course, you will have a working familiarity with the breadth of design’s past and present, theory and practice


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e67aedffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This task is the first part of a two-part research project that will support you to identify, contextualise, critically analyse and interpret relevant design practices through key theories and concepts in a range of different global contexts.

For Assessment 1, you will compile an annotated bibliography of quality research sources. The sources must be relevant to the essay question that will form the basis of your academic essay for Assessment 2.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"267aedffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e7aedffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa7aedffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e7aedffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Academic Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This task is the second part of a two-part research project that will support you to identify, contextualise, critically analyse and interpret relevant design practices through key theories and concepts in a range of different global contexts. Using the essay question you selected and the annotated bibliography you prepared for Assessment 1, you will write an academic essay.

contentlets.description: This course introduces a number of theoretical lenses for understanding contemporary design practice. The course takes you through key aspects of the current profession and discipline of design, explaining their histories. The course will focus on the principles and techniques of experts designing around the world. The course involves a series of researched case studies, giving you experiences of historically and culturally distinct ways of conducting design. Themes include: Craft and Design, Design Management, Consumerism, Design Education Institutions, Social Design, Design Futures, Design Methods, Post-Industrial Design. By the end of the course, you will have a working familiarity with the breadth of design’s past and present, theory and practice
contentlets.title: Design History and Theory 1

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9201","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9201 - Conservation, Registration and Handling","description":"

The collection, preservation and conservation of objects and artworks is a central role of the cultural sector. The way we understand objects and their relations to collections are changing. Likewise, new art practices and non-object based projects provide challenges to organisations whose mission is to display and preserve contemporary culture.


Professionals working with diverse collections need to be able to identify and comply with various and sometimes competing frameworks of significance and value when working with material culture. As well as examining the recording of collections and exhibitions, you will consider issues relevant to material preservation and conservation addressing debates of cultural sensitivity and significance in order to understand how collection policies determine what gets preserved in contemporary institutions. An understanding of these issues and adoption of these skills will ensure best practice when handling objects in both exhibition and collection management settings. This course will help you develop knowledge of the professional procedures required of galleries, museums and custodians of cultural heritage. The content will engage with leading arts organisations so that you will understand how these procedures operate within diverse gallery and institutional contexts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b1a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Significance Report / Exhibition Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Example Assessment Brief:

1.              Seek and find 5 objects from an institution or 5 artworks from a gallery or multiple galleries and request a loan. You must directly address the Director on a company letterhead (can be made up). Within this letter clearly state your intentions on what your project is and why you have chosen these particular works and how it’s going attribute the exhibition’s’ theme and development and what length of time you are requesting the work/s ?

2.              Organizing a Standard Facilities report (optional air con) and understanding of a Certificate of Currency

3.              Filling in a loan application requested from an institution

4.              Incoming Loan agreement – assign a loan number and  fill out to produce a contract between the lending party and your institution for the items requested on company letterhead (can be made up)

5.              Transportation – usually most reliable art handlers – research and find out who best to use for local, state, national and international freighting. Registering the items and condition reporting (where necessary), cleaning (if necessary) and storing in preparation of the installation.

6.              Manual handling requirements during installation, dollies, trolleys and pallet jacks – create processes that suit best your object/artwork within the space you are working with.

7.              Labels for the works – create an artwork label for the item you are displaying


This activity builds on in class-activities. Discussion will occur after these activities to provide an informal basis for the development of this project. Formal written feedback and the rubric will be returned after the submission of the report. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Object Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be allocated an object or artwork and the student will be required to complete a cataloguing worksheet which includes a photograph and a full condition report. This is based on the procedures undertaken as industry standard, and would be essential to completing the Vernon entry to create an object report. 

You will need to ensure your accuracy of descriptive and organizational details i.e. all required criteria (from a VERNON or KEMU database fields provide in the class worksheet) is filled in for a complete report. This includes accurate measurements and language

You will also be required to consider the following curatorial components: significance, provenance and valuation

Condition report – does the item require treatment of any kind?

Accuracy of Photography for Vernon including front, back and any conditional aspects (if any)

   


Informal discussion feedback provided about class activities. Formal written feedback and the rubric will be returned after the in-class test. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59a0b933db315c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Logistics and Transportation: Anticipating Risks and Hazards","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Packing and Crating:

1. Research different styles of companies who create moveable object/art crates. Utilise this information to develop a diagram of the best sized crate to accommodate your medium and weight of your object/artwork. 

Your diagrams should include the preservation and conservation safe materials used inside and out.

See the handouts on crating and packaging and ensure that you have enough materials to develop a travel crate for your object.


Students will have a workshop to prepare their packaging solutions, this will provide an informal means to gain feedback on their ideas. Students will present their packaging solution to the class and receive informal feedback then, with the final mark and rubric returned afterwards.

of Art & Design","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"SAHT9203 - Contemporary Creative Practices: Contexts","description":"

Contemporary Creative Practices: Contexts is a postgraduate course that examines the historical and theoretical contexts for major concepts in art, design and media practices in the 21st century. This course examines in depth two key themes across art, design and media art such as changing environments, creative experimentation and sustainable practice in order to critically discuss and historically contextualise creative practices.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"701638b7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3000 word essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

This assignment is designed to test your understanding of some of the critical themes in the course and your ability to address these in ways that demonstrate research skills and application; an ability to position your discussion in the context of relevant theoretical frameworks which are addressed in the course; and an ability to discuss art, design and media practices without depending solely on the analysis of other writers. Students will have a choice of a range of essay questions relating to the weekly themes.


Feedback will be provided via Review. Student submissions will be marked against the following criteria: 1. A coherent, well thought out discussion that clearly states its theme and convincingly demonstrates a viewpoint through the use of examples. 2. Research skills as demonstrated by the selection of appropriate evidence which supports the argument/s 3. An ability to position your discussion in the context of relevant social, historical and theoretical frameworks that are addressed in the course. 4. Written skills: clarity of expression, essay organization and structure. 5. Attention to presentation: title page, layout, margins, legibility, correct formatting of references in notes, bibliography.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f01638b7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ac16f4b7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will write 400 words each week in response to a question distribute din tutorials and related to the weekly topic.


Feedback will be provided via Review. The student responses will be marked against the following criteria: 1. A sound understanding of the weekly topic. 2. An ability to illustrate and explain critical concepts in the course. 3. A confidence in articulating informed analysis of works and concepts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c1638b7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e416f4b7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Analysis 1000 words","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Using ONE example from either art, design, architecture or media, students are to articulate the meaning of 'social practice'. 


Written feedback will be provided in response to the student submissions marked against the following criteria: 1. Provides a strong argument which critically discusses the chosen subject 2. Analytical skills as demonstrated by the selection of appropriate evidence which supports the argument/s 3. Ability to position the argument within broader contexts i.e. social and historical 4. Written and presentation skills: clarity of expression, essay organization and structure

contentlets.description: Contemporary Creative Practices: Contexts is a postgraduate course that examines the historical and theoretical contexts for major concepts in art, design and media practices in the 21st century. This course examines in depth two key themes across art, design and media art such as changing environments, creative experimentation and sustainable practice in order to critically discuss and historically contextualise creative practices.
contentlets.title: Contemporary Creative Practices: Contexts

This postgraduate course introduces you to recent histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art. The course locates art practices within wider social, cultural, political, and philosophical contexts, and introduces the histories of postmodernism, feminism, globalisation, decolonisation and other major frameworks that continue to shape contemporary art. The course focuses on art practices since the 1960s and examines how the rise of installation, performance and conceptual art have influenced the breakdown of traditional discipline boundaries. You will develop critical visual analysis skills through discursive tutorial activities, academic reading, writing and research tasks. You will be encouraged to work collaboratively to develop and share your analytic and reflective skills. This course will provide you with the background knowledge required to undertake independent creative enquiry in your chosen field.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"444f70ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical response file","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment is designed to provide you with an opportunity to respond to the lecture and course material. Each week (from week 2-8, not including study week) a question will be asked in the lecture which will be based on that week’s content. You are to respond in 300 words, using your understanding based on the lecture, tutorial discussions and set readings. Some additional research is recommended for clarification or extension (using the set readings is a great place to start). Your writing should be concise and clear, and directly respond to the question demonstrating knowledge of the weekly content. Your writing style should be academic, supporting your answers with evidence and analysis. You are encouraged to produce the responses consistently throughout the course.

THIS ASSESSMENT REQUIRES YOU TO:

  • Watch the lecture and get the Critical Response File Question.
  • Respond to the question (300 word each response), with the question and week number at the top of each response. You should have 6 in total.
  • Reference using APA referencing style with a bibliography.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3f3f70ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b33f70ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ff3f70ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"273f70ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Academic Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment is designed to develop skills in locating scholarly research, academic essay structure and writing and critical analysis. Being able to structure an academic argument is a key skill that will allow you to analyse creative practice (including your own) in a rigorous manner. Write a 2,200 word essay, based on one of the questions below, paying attention to scholarly presentation, which includes legibility, layout, correct formatting of references and bibliography. Use APA referencing style. Be sure to indicate what question you are attempting.

This assessment is complemented by the online academic skills lessons. Make sure you complete these to learn how to find appropriate research, structure and reference your essay. 

THIS ASSESSMENT REQUIRES YOU TO:

  • Choose one question from the list below.
  • Conduct scholarly research appropriate to the question and the content of the course.
  • Write a 2,200 word essay that answer the question that demonstrates academic writing skills.
  • Reference your essays and include a bibliography (in APA style).

ESSAY QUESTIONS (choose one):

  1. Artists propose, test and experiment through their art to expose and critique systems, contexts, identities and institutions. Using three artworks since 1960, demonstrate the unique ways artists have researched and presented ideas that challenge the audience’s “knowledge”.
  2. Postmodernist theory and art challenged the idea of the original artwork. Using two artworks from 1960-1990 discuss how the notion of the “original” was critiqued. How did these artworks comment on broader visual and consumer culture?
  3. Using three artworks (since 1960) explain two different creative strategies used to critique “gender”. Compare and contrast these strategies.
  4. Discuss the complexities of “post” colonial art in ongoing settler colonies like Australia. Analyse three artworks (since 1960) within the broader context of settler colonisation.
  5. Since the 1960’s artist have challenged traditional disciplinary boundaries. Analyse and contextualise the reasons for the breakdown of disciplinary boundaries through the practices of two artists (since the 1960’s).
  6. Biennales and Art Fairs have proliferated since the 1990’s producing “global” contemporary art. Discuss the effectiveness of three artworks (since 1990) that problematise and critique “global” art.

This course will examine the major ways in which photography has been theorised from its inception to the present. Key theories of photography studied include positivism, realism, formalist modernism, postmodernism and poststructuralism. Theorisations of the impact of digital technologies on the photographic medium will also be addressed. Theories examined in the course will be applied to historical and contemporary examples of photographic practice.

This course aims to challenge the mainstream view that Aboriginal art exists only in the Desert or the Top End regions of Australia through a study of exhibitions, writings and films from the seminal exhibition 'Koori Art 84' through to the present day. This course will provide the opportunity to investigate an arts paradigm that currently sits outside the general view of what consititues Australian art but conversely is seen as an integral force that initiates and drives many of the discussions that surround contemporary Australian art history and theory. Topics covered include photography, political art, established and emerging artists, the 'gentle arts', films, artists collectives, the role of media in the promotion of Aboriginal art, exhibitions, catalogues and art criticism. The course will include guest speakers who are at the forefront of their chosen area of practice or area of expertise. Students will investigate the presentation and treatment of Aboriginal art and artists at galleries and museums while also examining the changing theories/styles of catalogue writing and art criticism over the past 25 years.

Your presentation to the class will be based on these findings. A power-point presentation and a hard copy of your presentation must be handed in at the end of your presentation.

This course provides a critical introduction to the histories and theories of art institutions and exhibitions. The focus will be on the transformations in our public collections and museums and their role in our collective futures. You will be introduced to major frameworks and contexts through which museums and exhibitions have been understood. This will include institutional and exhibitionary analysis, approaches to objects and collections as well as key models of museum communication. Exhibitions are important sites for private reflection, the contestation of power as well as participation in public meaning making, this course will provide you with the foundation for involvement in these important cultural fields. You will also consider the impact of alternative approaches to curatorial practices in global networked culture. This course is designed to provide you with core knowledge of the discipline from which to develop your own critically reflective approach to professional practice. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"eaa0f933db315c50eb6b147a3a961949","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

In this assessment you will develop an essay outline that will form the basis of your final essay (Assessment 3). This assessment is designed to develop your skills in academic essay writing and institutional analysis. Structuring an academic argument is a key skill that will allow you to analyse museum practice (either your own or the work of others) critically and rigorously.

For this assessment you are required to:

  1. Choose an essay question from the list provided (or develop your own) that corresponds to a weekly theme from the course.
  2. Write an academic introduction that answers the question and outlines your argument. Your introduction should be edited and refined (200 words).
  3. Write a series of key points (between 3-5) addressing the main issues you intend to discuss in the body of your essay. Outline examples of you will be analysing (300 words).
  4. Write a bibliography containing 5-7 scholarly texts relevant to your essay question and argument. You must include at least two scholarly journal articles, which are less than 10 years old. Write short annotations outlining the key argument of the source and explaining the relevance of the article to your research.

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02a0f933db315c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

This assessment requires you to write a 2500 word academic essay based on your chosen topic (developed in Assessment 1). This assessment is designed to test your understanding of key themes in the course and strengthen your writing and research skills. Essay questions will be available from Moodle.

You will develop your essay over the semester and will receive ongoing feedback from your tutor and peers. You will be required to provide an additional 1-2 paragraph reflective statement addressing how you responded to the feedback from Task 1 including you focus for development.

You should pay close attention to scholarly presentation, including clear expression, legibility, essay structure, correct formatting of references and bibliography.

You should include a diversity of scholarly materials including journal articles, and recent literature (less than 10 years old). This course follows the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system. Guidelines on how to reference according to this system can be found at

https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnotebibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system and at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/citingdifferent-sources-0  and at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/bibliography-orlist-references    

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02a0f933db315c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In Week 1, students will form groups and will be allocated a week in which to present. Choose one institution/ site/ object/ or display to research. You will need to analyse this through the topic/themes set for discussion that week. For example, you may look at an example of museum communication in the Museums and Communication week or an example of how an audience perspective might challenge interpretations in the week The Museum’s Public(s): Difference and Inclusion. The aim is to present your chosen institution/ site/ object/ or display in a way that suits or is derived from, the set weekly reading(s).

The intention is to show you are familiar with the readings for this week and can discuss a museum or art gallery case study in relation to the set material. This is not just about applying the reading to new material, but discussing how your specified case studies speak back to the readings or show the limit of that framework too. 

You may wish to consider the following:

  1. The formal qualities of the institution/ site/ object/ or display
  2. The environment of the institution/ site/ object/ or display
  3. What analytic framework are you using? (e.g. semiotic, postcolonial, social history). Start with a critical review of the particular analytic framework of the reading.
  4. A brief idea of how you interpret this institution/ site/ object/ or display according to the analytic framework you have chosen.

Practical details:

> Group presentations are to be up to half-an-hour in duration. You, as a group, are to determine how your labour is distributed: write a contract as to what each member will do. (If you had to resolve difficulties as a group, document this.)

> You will all get the same mark for the presentation. 

> You will submit your presentation (Powerpoint or Google Slides) (including a bibliography) should be submitted to Moodle on day of presentation.

> In addition, each person needs to provide a brief 1-2 paragraph statement outlining their contribution to the group and the strengths & weakness of each participant. The aim is for you to reflect on your group contribution and consider how you work as part of a team.

> Presentations are to be delivered to the class, not simply read. A presentation that relies heavily on reading (except for quotes) will not score highly on the communication criteria.

> Ensure you know how to use any technology you wish to use. Use good quality images. 

>Think about different ways to engage the class and to convey your argument. You should raise issues and concepts related to the theme and the readings that will help your peers to understand the course materials from a new perspective. Engage the class in and encourage questions. You may ask the class, for example, to address a particular question in relation to the object/ exhibition or reading(s). Find a way to involve the class, e.g. discussion, debate, questions, exercise, analysis.

contentlets.description: This course provides a critical introduction to the histories and theories of art institutions and exhibitions. The focus will be on the transformations in our public collections and museums and their role in our collective futures. You will be introduced to major frameworks and contexts through which museums and exhibitions have been understood. This will include institutional and exhibitionary analysis, approaches to objects and collections as well as key models of museum communication. Exhibitions are important sites for private reflection, the contestation of power as well as participation in public meaning making, this course will provide you with the foundation for involvement in these important cultural fields. You will also consider the impact of alternative approaches to curatorial practices in global networked culture. This course is designed to provide you with core knowledge of the discipline from which to develop your own critically reflective approach to professional practice.
contentlets.title: Exhibiting Cultures

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9311","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9311 - Curatorial Studio: Social Space","description":"

Contemporary curatorial practice is increasingly preoccupied with notions of public engagement and participation, in the context of debates over Relational Aesthetics, socially engaged arts practice and the relationship of art and activism.  Curatorial Studio: Curating in Social Space enables students to operate creatively, critically and effectively within this context as both initiators and collaborators. 


This studio aims to equip students with a critical understanding of some of the key theoretical and practical issues confronting curators working in “social space”. The studio is aimed at those wishing to extend the curatorial field beyond existing audiences of the “white cube” to reach variegated, specific and diverse publics both within and without gallery spaces. Through this studio students will critically evaluate notions of “community”, “participation”, “collaboration” and “public” to develop their own ideas on how to construct an encounter between “audience”, “social praxis” and “art”. 


This course will provide real life situations, supported by partnerships with experienced individuals and institutions, where students can develop their own independent approaches to curating in social situations.  By the end of the course students will have chosen a specific community within which to work, developed a curatorial premise, produced a project text, and curated a project. Students will develop skills in determining who is their intended audience, attempting to reach that audience, and evaluating how successfully their project has operated within the defined social space.


This studio will equally weight participatory, collaborative, curatorial and textual components encouraging students to engage with the complexity of how curatorial knowledge is produced and activated. This studio will encourage self-reflexivity by integrating forms of self-assessment within external assessment procedures. 


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ff5fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Curatorial project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Part 1: Practical Component

Part 2: Written Component: Report (1500 words)

This task involves conceptualising, planning, delivering and documenting a curatorial project in a public/social space. The course cohort will work from Week 4 onwards in sub-groups on one main project. These sub-groups reflect the core aspects of a successful project: curatorial liaison, production, communications, documentation and dissemination. According to the tasks assigned to your sub-group you will work on the development of curatorial themes, planning of content delivery, consultation with stakeholders, logistics (technical requirements, fundraising, permissions, install and de-install plans), creation and circulation of promotional materials, creation of documentation and where relevant publication (print or digital) and post-production activities.

For Part One: Practical Component you will receive a group mark for your sub-group work (30%) and a mark for individual performance (30%).

Following the delivery of the project for Part Two of this task you are required to submit a written report that summarises and evaluates your work on the curatorial project, including your role in any sub-groups. The report should demonstrate sustained working process and include visual materials. It should  refer back to and assess the key curatorial ideas and practices that were employed, analyse the outcomes in terms of successes and challenges where relevant, and consider strategies moving forward.

Throughout the process of working on the curatorial project you should track your experiences as an individual working in the sub-group, and document any relevant work. You can use this textual and visual material to form the basis of your report. The two criteria that assess Part Two of the Task are assessed individually and are each weighted at 20%.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"375fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"735fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f35fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f75fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"235fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Curatorial project ideas","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to present their ideas for the course curatorial project in the form of a 5-minute presentation in class. The overall brief for the project will be presented by the lecturer in Week One. The presentation can include examples of relevant artists and creative work, and references to the theory and practice (past events or projects) of curating in social space. It should highlight the project areas that the student can contribute to and their skills: areas of project group work will be outlined in Week 1. The presentation should be speculative and imaginative but feasible and relevant to our context in Sydney. Use a presentation format such as Keynote or Powerpoint to present visuals and brief text: given the time, aim for 5-10 slides maximum, depending on your slide design.

You are marked individually on this task; however, your participation in the group discussions is an important support for developing your ideas. In class, students will both present their own presentation (assessed) and respond to the presentations of their peers (non-assessed but again an important part of your academic development on the course). The presentations will be timed to and it is strongly advised that you practice your presentation.

A draft of this presentation should be uploaded to Moodle before class in Week 3 for feedback.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SAHT9312","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9312 - Curatorial Studio: Site and Situation","description":"

This curatorial studio supports you to operate creatively, critically and effectively within the contexts of site specific and public art. It provides opportunities to analyse real-world public art projects and to extend and apply this knowledge as you develop your own curatorial project outside of conventional exhibition spaces. The course focuses on historical debates and contemporary theories that frame curatorial practices in public space. It connects you with emerging ideas about site specificity, performance and temporary events, social engagement, modes of spectatorship and participation, as well as strategies of intervention, collaboration, and appropriation. From this informed position, you will be supported to develop collaborative, speculative and experimental curatorial approaches that incorporate project planning and delivery strategies for working in non-traditional scenarios.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SAHT9690 - Special Project","description":"

From time to time, one-off opportunities arise for the College to offer special programs of study for credit. For example, supervised international experiences such as study tours. This course is intended to facilitate the College in developing its educational program for postgraduate students by incorporating such opportunities into the academic program. Specific course outlines will be distributed detailing the academic content, objectives, assessment tasks and criteria, modes of teaching and learning, expectations and requirements of student participation. Please note that there may be costs involved (such as costs associated with travel, accommodation, meals and museum visits) in taking this course.
